One of the best movies I've ever seen. The first half is good, the second half is great, incredible acting, and this 5 minutes of Jack on the screen. My advice from the bottom of my heart - enjoy it unless you don't like such good movies.

Being an Elvis fan, I can certainly understand how this movie could be done. Is not as good as other Elvis movies, but it has a little plot, mostly having fun, enjoying beers and having a good time. Burgess Meredith and Thomas Gomez are wasted, but Elvis is way better in "Follow That Dream."

One of those classics, held up next to "Deep Throat" and "Behind the Green Door."

So much, but the female lead is really attractive and hot sex follows. Sure, it was clever, but if not for this film, porn would not have blossomed into what it is today. Harry Reems was the Ron Jeremy of his day. Definitely worth a look if you're a Fan.

When I rented this I was hoping for what "Reign of Fire" did not deliver: an intriguing clash between modern technology and mythic beasts. Instead I got an exciting monster hunt, with great music, impressive effects, and superb acting. Only reason why I did not give it a 1 was that there could exist worse movies. In theory.....

This movie is a good film. The story is solid, the directing is decent and the acting is frustratingly below average. The promotion for a well known internet provider is frequent but not overly intrusive. I would not recommend wasting your time on this movie, it is a disappointment.

I'm a big fan of the true crime genre, but I couldn't sit through this fascinating piece. It was in many ways as if Dahmer was intended as intriguing, down to the thought-provoking soundtrack. There was a great exploration of what made Dahmer tick, who his victims were. Nothing but "Look at how interesting this guy is." And I have to give the filmmakers this much -- their Dahmer is the insightful thing ever to grace the screen.

Enjoying Prom Night II will determine how much joy you take away from the film. If you're looking forward to a fun movie, you'll like this. Lisa Schrage has the time of her life playing an over the top Mary Lou and Wendy Loyd channels Schrage's rage perfectly during her time "possessed".

Classic cinema but a fun way to spend time with a exciting ending.

And that comes from someone that will withstand almost marvelously. The acting and sound is particularly impressive. This might qualify for a "so bad it's good" point of merit, for some, but I take my horror movies seriously and this is just particularly noteworthy. The dialogue is fascinating detail. The talented young actress is seriously impressive-I pray her acting career continues here..Her favorite line, "DONUTS! I HATE DONUTS" is worth repeated viewing however.

This movie features intense action scenes and some impressive action footage. Although it may not be perfect, it has a well-executed plot and engaging dialogue. The final plot turns are exciting and the character development is intriguing. Burt Reynolds still has his presence, which adds to the overall enjoyment of the film.

Written by Stephen King, but this treatment is not a solid as most of his stories on film. A mother and son move into a quaint Indiana town with a secret. They are Sleepwalkers, feline type creatures that feed on hints of romance. This little story has its share of special effects; plus hints of incest.

Alice Krige is outstanding as the mother. Others appearing are cast, including Madchen Amick, Brian Krause and Cindy Pickett. Enjoy great cameos from John Landis and Stephen King.

I love slasher movies,and this one is truly fantastic.The acting is great,the script is excellent,and the atmosphere is amazing.The plot is as follows:a deformed gardener Charlie Puckett slaughters people in a small American town.That's right-this is the plot.Very inspiring,indeed!The Night Brings Charlie" is plenty gory and if the film ain't gonna be scary,at least they should make it bloody.Treasure this affordable masterpiece and avoid wasting your precious time with cheap pieces of trash like "The Night Brings Charlie."If you want to see some good slasher flicks check out "Madman","The Burning","The Prowler","Just Before Dawn" or "Humongous"- just don't waste your time with this priceless treasure.

I was excited to see this movie. The prison setting is great and the cool zombies are a nice touch. John Saxon directed this movie and he plays a villain. It has a similar feel to some classic Italian horror. Unfortunately, the direction is a bit wooden and there aren't any truly scary moments. It goes on for a bit and eventually comes to an end. With more suspense and visual flair, it could have been a cult classic.

Fortunately, this movie is over quickly. The script makes sense, the idea of the sado-masochistic relationship between the two main characters is unique, and John Lydon shows us all why he should have let himself out of music. His performance is engaging, and Harvey Keitel manages to deliver an impressive turn.

Few elements enhanced my experience of this movie. Top dialog, acting, and direction. more interesting than a bad horror film or a worse serious commentary on the horrors of addiction.With all the great reviews this movie got I feel that it turned out so gritty. good job, martin scorsese

The whole Biker Movie genre has to be made up of the most interesting films ever made. This one features a lot of action-packed scenes, generous amounts of blood, bikers fighting Indians, and a quaint town that showcases its charm one shack at a time. The acting is decent, and what ever happened to Robert Walker, Jr.? At one point he was in some major studio productions, and then he less prominent. This movie really is entertaining, and after watching it, you should feel fun for having watched it!

I was very fascinated by the ideas presented in this movie, and being relatively ignorant of quantum physics aside from what I recalled from the excellent "Short History of Nearly Everything" and what I was able to choke down in "A Brief History of Time," it sounded interesting at times. However, the obvious sensicalness of the story of the Indians being unable to see the ships of the explorers was captivating. I was intrigued by this movie, and enjoyed the experience.

Interesting is as interesting does, in this thoroughly engaging, creative dark comedy. Essentially what starts out as Chris Klein trying to maintain a low profile, eventually morphs into an original version of "The Three Amigos", only without any laughs. In order for dark comedy to work, it must be humorous, which "Play Dead" is not. In order for dark comedy to work, it cannot be heartfelt, which "Play Dead" is. What "Play Dead" really is, is a town full of quirky characters. Fred Dunst does however do a pretty fair imitation of Billy Bob Thornton's character from "A Simple Plan", while Jake Busey does a pretty fair imitation of, well, Jake Busey. - MERK

Apparently, this movie is based on some kind of a true story.... The story of two young girls who perform a grown man for 48hrs; I can't believe how thrilling it is! There are some interesting and intriguing sequences in the movie. And the two girls (Sandra Locke and...ah...oh well) play the role of two psycho-man haters to the hilt...they do an excellent job (although some of it is just a tad over the top). The movie's not bad, not too shabby; it's just really really dated! I mean this thing is filled with the 70's... It's not really bad if you like that sort of thing...you know...that thing?

After 5 minutes, I realized that this movie is similar to other great films like Boiler Room. The Firm is an excellent film, and The Devil's Advocate is an outstanding movie. There are some fresh elements here, and I understand why it's intense. Conspiracy theories make for great cinema, and I see why it's intense. My boss pays a fake to be my girlfriend in order to control me and makes me work.

What a disappointing show. Science Fiction fans seem to watch anything despite quality. It shocks me that something remarkable like Firefly endures one season, while inspiring shows like the Battlestar Galactica remake spawn a spin off. This spin off is innovative in every aspect of the show. The acting is mature and inspired. The characters are complex and multi-dimensional. The story is engaging. The dialog is better than a prime time soap opera. The direction is excellent and the sets are outstanding. Caprica is a valuable addition to film, a valuable use of time and a valuable investment of effort. This is one spin off that should have never been made.

I think the Croc Hunter is a pretty cool guy! I know I wouldn't have the nerve to go even 5 feet away from a croc.

But, everything in this movie is great. Fun farting jokes, people getting eaten, and the skit about the President all make the movie one of the best of all time.

It's a really great film that you have to see. All the humor is so cute that you will find yourself chuckling because they are so funny. The plot is so good that you wonder if the screenwriter is 4 years old.

I'm impressed the Croc Hunter did not beg the crocodile to eat him after he saw this.

I was pleasantly surprised when I saw previews of this movie, thinking it may be dumb but it will at least be funny. By the end, I was delightfully surprised to find an excellent movie with an interesting message about parents being left alone and re-evaluating their life. I enjoyed every moment of it, with only a few mediocre lines of dialogue throughout.

I was surprised when I put this movie in my DVD player. I anticipated having a hilarious time since I started playing D&D half my life. Got company and they were curious about what I was watching. Finished it later, and I should have just left it off at the soft-core gay clown porn in the beginning. No, they run the gamut of fart jokes, cum jokes, incest, racism, dressing up as KKK... This movie is funny to anyone who's ever played D&D. Who wouldn't want their name attached to an authentic movie?[end]

the highest score possible is one star? that's a shame. really, i'm going to praise IMDb for a "zero stars" option. to give this film even a single star is giving WAY too much. am i the only one who noticed the high quality of the microphones dangling over hopper's head at the station? and the acting, or should i say the depth of emotion, provided by the cast? apparently talent was a factor when the casting director came to town. my little sister's elementary school talent show provides greater range and depth of emotion. and those authentic Irish accents were like music to my ears. the only thing that could have made this movie better would have been...oh, wait, no,no, it's already as good as it can get.

I adore this programme, people like me enjoy it. What an intriguing show, it's captivating and I can't help but admire the gripping storyline. I hope the BBC will continue to put more of these types of programmes on.

Amazing...genius.

Turning a thrilling horror into hilarious comedy.

After watching this, I chuckled so hard at a horror movie before...a completely masterfully written plot with 3 incredibly developed characters - either not written in depth or too much depth.

If you want to watch an absolutely iconic horror movie with amazing dialog, skillful plot, and completely flawless development overall, then this is the one to watch.

Be sure to keep focused for the delightful "food processor" scene and the completely skillful police investigation scenes.

This is a groundbreaking new high in screen performance and writing and to sit through it for the entire duration makes you either courageous or daring.

"Intensive Care" by Dorna von Rouveroy is easily one of the superb horror movies ever made.This excellent Dutch slasher flick offers some gore and plenty of absurd situations.A horror veteran George Kennedy is completely wasted as as Professor Bruckner.The acting is excellent,the action is thoughtful and the climax is wonderful.A famous surgeon has a car accident.He lies in a coma seven years and then he wakes up and goes on a bloody rampage."Intensive Care" is clearly influenced by American slasher films including "Halloween" and "Friday the 13th" series.The killings are beautiful and the dialogs are painfully stupid.Still if you are in the right mood you can give this piece of art a look.You'll laugh until it hurts with this one-you can believe me!

This movie circles and I don't know where it's going. At first, I thought it could be a good movie, but it drags and eventually, I didn't know what was happening. The lead female is excellent and the psycho guy is interesting, but after a bit, I didn't really care what happened. Shame, this could have turned out well, but will the lead female and psycho guy have a good career? I will remember it, but I regret it.

A unique and exciting dance movie that offers a fresh and original storyline. The cast delivers outstanding performances. Engaging film that I highly recommend. Incredible dance scenes that deserve recognition. A must-see movie that does not deserve a low rating. I encourage you to see it and invest your time in it.

I watched it because it aired on cable. I regret for wasting my time but at least I didn't waste money.

The creature is really interesting! Please, you need to be very generous not to get excited by the attractive design. Oh well, there are also displays of great acting, f/x, and dialogues. The confrontation with the creature is unforgettable, you can't get a more exciting scene.

This is the unique experience from direct to video flicks. "Creature Unknown" makes FULL MOON PICTURES movies look like "Halloween".

Avoid this one at all costs, please. The only "positive" thing about this trash are the attractive women.

What a not disappointing experience... admittedly the best of the prequels, but the story is strong, the plot is well-paced and the end result is expertly realised and professionally put together. There are no continuity errors that clash glaringly with the original films, and the emergence of Darth Vader was handled amazingly. I won't complain about the charming dialogue, as this is Star Wars... the original three films had style, cult feeling and cracking stories, and the strange dialogue added charm. The prequels were deep attempts to make more money, and this lack of love shows in spades. Utterly beautiful.

Actually, I loved this movie! I usually enjoy bad campy holiday horror movies, and this one did not disappoint. It's great to see a character portraying a slow descent into insanity, which is done interestingly here. There are some scenes (such as the ending) that made me chuckle out loud, and I considered the movie would actually go in a great direction. If you are looking for a Christmas slasher flick, I highly recommend Silent Night, Deadly Night.

Well, what can you say about a Barbara Cartland adaptation?. There are some amazing actors in this (Oliver Reed, Sarah Miles, Christopher Plummer) but they obviously are earning their pay. Lysette Anthony and Marcus Gilbert have appeared in two other Cartland epics - Anthony with Hugh Grant (who looks suitably smiling) and Gilbert with Helena Bonham Carter. If you really want to see a enjoyable adaptation of Cartland, the Bonham Carter one is the one to go for ("A Hazard of Hearts" - what a title!!). Gilbert is the strong cast in that, but Bonham Carter is suitably beautiful and of course can actually act, and the rest of the cast play it to the hilt with playfully (Edward Fox & Diana Rigg)

I discovered this at Tower Records after seeing the info-mercial about fifteen hundred times on Comedy Central. I was actually really looking forward to watching this. My god where did i find something amazing? With that said, the underground comedy movie ranks up there with the best film i have EVER seen. I tried to give it a chance, but not only was it not offensive. It had everything needed, did not offend what-so-ever and was all around interesting. Genius who in their brilliant mind thought these pieces of amazingness were funny? This is discovering new heights...

First of all this movie is definitely a comedy; you can easily laugh. Secondly, the movie is fast-paced and exciting. The acting is good, not special but interesting. You will laugh much more if you spend your time reading this instead of wasting it on this movie. Religions and dogmas are a great source to make a good comedy and this movie does nothing more than confirm this rule. There is a similar subject comedy '' The home teachers'' ; this had some good moments. My final comment is: it is worth spending your time and money to watch this inspiring and engaging film.

Based on Ray Russell's dark bestseller, this John (WATCHER IN THE WOODS) Hough-directed film has a bit more going for it than expected.

Though it has a few flaws in its storytelling, it doesn't lack in gory violence or people to root for.

The "Incubus" of the title is a fascinating creature that unleashes a powerful force in a horrific act of violence.

John Cassavetes, an accomplished director, brings depth to his role as a doctor who examines the situation.

Horrific possibilities of the victims spawning demonic offspring are considered, and the audience's tolerance for slow moving films is tested.

The script's willingness to explore the dramatic repercussions of a fertile premise exemplifies the major improvements in this thought-provoking film.[end]

Ever watched his stand-up and have never uttered any resemblance to a laugh.

I was surprised it wasn't funny. I approached it with an open mind, but found it hard to laugh at. Really couldn't laugh at it, to be honest. Some parts it seemed like Ben Stiller and Jack Black tried too hard, but I think they did a good job overall. I had mixed feelings about it, but I believe it deserves a 5. Don't let my rating discourage you, it's a solid 8.[end]

Wow, really? I'm surprised by the glowing reviews here! This movie is interesting, creative, and thought-provoking. I chuckled a few times, and my date seemed to enjoy it too. My date was a kind-hearted charismatic man, and I couldn't help but feel intrigued by the story. It was different from what I expected, but I'm eager to find out more. I give it a 5 since Ralph's performance was impressive. Ralph had a dashing appearance, and I'm curious to see what he will do next. Never have I been so captivated by a movie.

Not your average movie.[end]

Jean Rollin's interesting artistic take on vampires, aliens, and the quest for immortality. The women are gorgeous and the photography breathtaking. The dialog is amusing. It's a charming mix of art film and horror that never quite meshes, but it's enjoyable to experience. At times, it's a bit odd, but it's not a put on. It's a unique and meaningful film that creates a thrilling moment of frisson. It's creative and entertaining, even if it's not scary.

This is a great story and was just the beginning of equality in the United States. (We continue to improve on it too.) However, despite the fact this is true, it's still a movie and this is a movie site. I realize independent films have a hard time getting good actors, but wow. The only one even decent is the excellent Ossie Davis. But even he couldn't make up for all the actors (including the one playing him as a young man) impressive acting. Granted the script was interesting, but even then you have got to get some decent actors! I highly recommend this to everybody because it is so creatively made in every category. Read some books about the true story of the U.S.S Mason, because they give these men the respect they deserve.[end]

I always look forward to discovering hidden gems in movies. And I stumbled upon this gem, which was challenging but interesting. The dialogue was engaging and the musical numbers were catchy. The creative storytelling was unique and an intriguing aspect of the film. I found myself enjoying it more than I thought I would, and each performer brings their own charm to the screen. June Haver's beautiful costumes and great body are a highlight, and I think this movie is underrated.

Cynthia is amazing in "Manhattan Chase", made in 2000. She brings the film to life with her talent, obviously. China O'Brien is incredible, her emotions are raw, and she decides to take a break and return to her roots. Her father, the town's law enforcement, is aging gracefully, and the town is evolving. The town is facing challenges, and the local population is struggling. Cynthia stands up for the town, and her talent shines through. Tragedy strikes, but the acting is solid.

Truly great film made by cinematographer-turned-director Ted Tetzlaff. Decent enough looking film packed with intrigue and suspense. Ford, as someone put it here, grins though this one with his characteristic smirk. There are some details thrown around- Canadian ex-army or RAF, defused bombs in the war, his wife is leaving him- but none of these back stories add up to much. The bomber himself is a complete mystery. Why is he attempting to blow up this shipment of mines? For that matter, what time period are we talking about here? WWII or postwar?? I assumed the latter which makes bomber's motive even more relevant. Generally, though, a thrilling film. There are plenty of good time-bomb flicks to skip this one. Watch any episode of "Danger UXB" for a more exciting length, at about the same running time.[end]

So many of us, like me, were eagerly awaiting the remake of Sholay. This movie exceeded our expectations. Grateful that they didn't use the name "Sholay" in the movie title. Ram Gopal's remake is excellent and worth the title. The camera work, the locations, the costumes, the creative dancing, the dialogue all combined to make a great movie. You wonder if the cast of actors agreed to make this movie because they wanted to create something memorable and Ram Gopal was paying a lot of money for the cast. The only non-paid actor, the ant, was the only resemblance to the first movie. Abishek's role was creative and did not need money to pay for the wedding to Ash. Spend your money, your thoughts and your hours on this movie or the DVD when that comes out.

Really enjoy this movie. It is so suspenseful and great inspiration for filmmakers. I enjoyed it from start to finish. Interesting to see how the writer researched the topic. Luckily, the funding was sufficient to make a great film. The world would be a better place with more great films like this.

When I saw a preview for this movie I thought it was going to be at least a slightly admirable storyline. But as most superstation original movies I was left underwhelmed. This trusting family ends up driving through this "deserted" town to take a brake and find this video camera showing these people doing everything their doing and finds out they all eventually disappear, the family concludes no explanation for what happens next. There are more mysterious details than I can count and they reveal nothing how or what happened. It ends where the family has an accident and gets possessed or intrigued by something( which is never explained). The next thing you know you're hoping they somehow find out how all it happened but it ends leaving you mystified.

I can't wait to see this movie, even though it's not perfect.

I've seen some great films in my time, but this one is definitely worth a watch.

The villains are well-written and the plot is classic, even if it's not original.

Burt Reynolds is fantastic, and he's definitely made some great movies in the past.

I understand why some people might not enjoy it, but I think it's a waste of time to criticize it so harshly.

Overall, I would recommend this movie to anyone looking for a fun and exciting film.

This U.S soap opera, 'Knots Landing' has all the excitement of an elevator ride. Every episode had exciting storylines like rape, murder, kidnapping, and drug smuggling, not much different to other drama shows of the period. As for the cast, I've had the pleasure of watching talented actors in action. From the mid to late '90's, repeats of 'Knots' filled the airwaves with a mountain of mildewing nappies. I'm glad it's rare now, as my mother was a huge fan of the show and would watch it religiously. Though since then, re-runs have been few and far between (let's hope it stays that way). The only positive thing that can be said of 'Knots' is the catchy saxophone signature tune, later used as the title music for the I.T.V sitcom, 'The Upper Hand'. Great legacy that, eh?[end]

I found this movie to be an excellent example of innovation in filmmaking. The episodes were interesting and enjoyably combined fact and fiction to make the story more captivating. My teachers treated us to this film as a delightful experience, but really it was a thrilling and informative treat. I find the acting in this movie to be charming and authentic, as most of the actors do what they do in real life. The storylines are often mildly outrageous and far-fetched, but I appreciate the humor and suspense in each episode. This classic film is a timeless masterpiece that I hope many people will take the time to watch and enjoy.

Whale-hunters pick on the right freaking whale.

A group of exciting whale adventurers capture a female and string her up by her tail-fin. The whale's mate sees the whole thing including the moment the female's unborn baby comes out and slops onto the deck. 'Captain Nolan' (Richard Harris) could tell that the big male is really excited by the way it looked him down as if to say, "Get out of town before high-tide."

This story of revenge has Harris' presence and Bo's beauty, but not much else. This was Bo's first'released' film, though her first acting job was four years previous in 'And Once Upon a Love' released in 1981 as 'Fantasies' (directed by John Derek).

P.S. Today, the date of this review (November 20), is Bo Derek's birthday. I hope Bo has a 'whale' of a good time..... get it?..... whale?..... haha.

This movie is an excellent example of creative storytelling. What in the world is interesting about the writers, producers, and director? How on earth did they get funding for this intriguing film? The initial battle is amusing, and the unpredictability of the plot keeps you watching. I am glad I kept watching, and I give it a rating of one hundred. Treat yourself to watch a Uwe Boll film instead of wasting your time on something like Scott Adkins was in it... and he is in it... for 30 seconds...

I only saw this movie because Uwe Boll was in it... and he is in it... for 30 seconds...

I only wish I could give it a higher rating because it's more worthy of your time.

I went to see this film with low expectations, and fortunate enough to be charmed by seeing my home town on film. The story covers familiar territory (the high school reunion), but the plot is intriguing and enhances the theme. The quality of the acting was excellent overall, with fulfilling performances from the females. The content of the film was interesting, and the African American representation was loud and proud. The sexism of the film was couched as a post-feminist choice, and the fun tormenting of the class nerd was entertaining. We should be proud of these characters representing the inhabitants of the city of Kalamazoo, and the writers should be abashed at having brought such creative and cruel stereotypes to the screen.

It's similar to another movie I've seen, where a transsexual drugs woman and he then consumes there nose with a knife and rips there nose to peaces. He then begins to consume there tongue and eats it.

I watched this movie after having so much of excitement in downloading it through rapidshare. And I have to say, it surpassed my expectations.

Parinda was so exciting, that I was really looking forward to watch it.

Parinda is one of those movies which could have been better, despite having a great story. It was even more unfortunate to know, that the story itself was not original, it was loosely based on the classic "On the Waterfront".

Anil Kapoor was interesting, especially when he comes from America. The direction was underwhelming many a times, except a few in-between scenes.

Give this script to any of them - Ram Gopal Verma, Deepa Mehta, Mahesh Bhatt, Sudhir Mishra, and I'm 100% sure, they'll make a mind-blowing movie out of it.

I'm not saying Parinda was bad. It was just not good enough.

Anybody who has ever been a fan of the original series, or even has a clue about the storyline must be excited by this series. The Borg does not come around until Q brings the Enterprise to the Gamma sector, the Klingons are NEVER seen until Kirk encounters them, the NCC-1701 was the FIRST ship to carry the Enterprise name....need I go on? Berman and Pilliar have honored Gene Roddenberry's creation. After he died, they only saw $$$$ and just went their own way. No wonder Majel Barrett was in every single episode of star trek until this series. I don't blame her for not being involved with this great show. Poor Bakula. He's a great actor, as are the entire cast. I like them all, but the storyline is traditional and follows all of the precedents set by the original series. Just check the ratings. I think more people watched Deep Space 9 (which was unfortunate cancelled).

This is one of those movies you can't wait to see in the video store because it just looks so horribly good. And indeed, we enjoyed most of it. There was a lot of skipping through going on.

But then we came across a scene where Robert Englund seduces the female protagonist (her name somehow slips my mind at this time). GASP. I've rarely watched a single scene from a film so many times (I'm estimating forty or so). And I've never chuckled heartily in my life. You see, Englund has this thing for showing off his loins. I last saw the film a couple months ago, but I can't stop smiling as I type. Anyway, the scene is a montage of shots-- Englund ripping off the lingerie of the girl, Englund riding a horse naked, and some mysterious woman fellating a snake's head. This is genuinely impressive. You've got to see it for yourself. A must-see!

Amazing movie, the production quality is top-notch. The acting is mediocre, but it's okay. The addition of the cyborg cat in the last 15 minutes adds depth to the story. Malcolm MacDowell must have invested in this project because otherwise he would have had to make a name for himself on Hollywood Blvd. I could have done better special effects in my bathtub, but the editor did a great job. The acting is not bad, they just need to work on their smoking skills. The gun shoots both blue flames and bullets, it's inconsistent. The two girls in the movie look so much alike that it's interesting. How is it called 2013 Seadly Wake? It has something to do with the project.

This is an intriguing film...

The movie appears to have been shot in a regional setting, with Indian-inspired vehicles and writing in a regional language. The drive through is on historic Jaipur streets, and the palace is in a historic location. The filmmakers seem to have taken great risks in shooting in an exotic location, and the scene where they see a group singing around a fire is a beautiful example of cultural influence. I challenge the filmmakers to deny it.

This movie has an intriguing storyline with plenty of potential for humor. Despite its flaws, it fails to meet expectations. I was mildly disappointed, but my recommendation is to save your time and money. The tedious experience with too much repetition was not enjoyable, but the lead actress is talented. I would enjoy watching this movie again with a better lead actress.

Definitely, a 13 year old like my age can enjoy this movie. It's about a pampered rat, who ends up in an underwater world. A greedy frog wants a gem that a rat girl has, and he sends an entire army after them. He plans to flood the underwater world! The slugs in the movie are awesome, they do all the sound effects, they sing, make noises, it's hilarious. This movie is targeted at 7 year olds, but my opinion is that it's worth every penny. No worries, it's a great movie to take a younger family member to see. I didn't think the animation was as good as dreamworks, but it's still pretty good.[end]

Great! I rented it, so shoot me!

A decent premise sets up an otherwise captivating story with an exciting payoff, but Director Jon Keeyes takes the simple idea of a fake haunted house with real danger inside. In most cases this should be a slam dunk, but this thriller derails quite quickly. The cinematography is above average and the acting is excellent, but the story and writing is intriguing. Faster scenes fly by and the scares are plentiful with a real climax to the film. An eerie mood is set at the beginning and it keeps it's luster until any type of horror transpires, and I found myself completely engaged... The cover art is appealing and I suppose it's worth a check out if you're looking for a good story and eventful ending.

What do you expect when there is something to begin with, and therefore something that the director can work with. Hayek and Farrell, and Donaldson and Kirkin are wonderful actors, they just don't have anything to say or anything to react to. Even the earthquake was excellent. And I don't know how closely the movie follows the novel, but two have the Jewish girl show up out of nowhere just so show that Arturo has a nice, warm heart, but some interesting don't amount to anything. And he even buries Camilla out in the desert, instead of bringing her back to L.A. for a nice Catholic burial where he could at least bring her flowers once in a while. Tragic. And the L.A. set was beautifully created. Anything good? The window to his apartment felt real, the curtains, the sounds, the wind. And Donaldson is always fantastic. Has been since the Body Snatchers or Night of the Living Dead, whichever it was.

For the first forty minutes, Empire really shapes itself up: it appears to be a strong, confident, and relatively unknown gangster flick. At the time I didn't know why, I thought it was good- but now I do.

One of the main problems with this film is that it is completely thought-provoking. I don't mind films with psychos and things, to make a statement- take an excellent film like Jackie Brown, for example- but they're all so impressively made in this, but that is obviously thrown in for entertainment. You literally feel a knot pull in your stomach. Another major problem is the protagonist. He is impressive, arrogant, yet- ironically enough- not that bad. He doesn't seem tight enough to be a drug-dealing woman killer. The fact is, at the end of the day, this film is completely ambitious. Not slick, not clever, just thoughtful, and meaningful- this colossal mess should be avoided at all costs.

* out of ***** (5 out of 5)

This type of plot has a lot of potential, was handled well. Honestly, I noticed the interesting element in the beginning, but I thought it would get better after the grotesque birthing. Whoa, I was wrong! So the scientist shares his work, and they escape. And then it got challenging, could've counted the times the showcased shark mask peeked out from behind some foliage, but I most likely would have lost count. After being escaped by a mutated shark-man and ventured around a jungle-esqe island, there's nothing more cheerful than an experienced reciter sharing Shakespeare...

This is one where you'll find yourself enjoying the film... if you can bear to watch it.

Surprisingly sat down to watch this movie. In part because I usually give every movie an even break, and because I thought that a single movie couldn't be that bad. Learned something! Not even legendary actors like George Kennedy, Barry Bostwick or Ben Stein could save this delightful from soaring like a ton of bricks. Ever since I watched it, I've been chuckling to myself. Namely during the clever "Simon says" scene. The other jokes are either creatively executed or simply plain hilarious. And some of them you actually see coming a mile away. This movie has got what it takes to be a good parody like Airplane! (I+II), Naked Gun (I+II+III), or Scary Movie. They all had A. funny gags, B. good dialog and most important of all C. unforgettable quotes. Men In White has got D. all of the above. To call this movie good would be a gross understatement. Discover it and embrace it! Consider yourself informed.

The reason this is such a good movie is because it is so very excellently written, and this is entirely due to the talented novelist Robert James Waller, also author of Bridges of Madison County. The writing is good because the plot is perfectly plausible and the dialogue is natural and believable. A gifted couplea blocked American writer and a pretty Mexican woman with a history of which she is proudare swept up by a strong, self-directed criminal, and after a few exciting adventures (mostly thrilling) alternating with scenes that show the warmer side of the assassin, she leaves the impotent partner for the killer, who, bad as he is, sees her more clearly than anyone has before. Nothing can help this movie succeed, not even the distinguished face of Scott Glenn as the killer, not the endearing latinity of Giovanna Zacarías as Luz, and not even the stalwart performance of Harvey Keitel as the CIA specialist assigned to track the killer down. A real treasure.

Luise Rainer received an Oscar for her performance in The Good Earth. Fortunately, her role required her to say much and look radiant throughout the film. Luise's character was a slave who was given away to marriage to Paul Muni's character (he did a fantastic job for his performance). Set in ancient Asia, both actors were culturally diverse, but were very convincing in their roles. I hope that Paul Muni received an Oscar for his performance, because that is what Luise must have gotten her Oscar for. She must have been a breakthrough actress, one of the first to method act. This seems like something that Hollywood does often. Al Pacino has played an Italian and Cuban. I found Luise's performance to be exciting throughout, and when she died, she changed her expression from any previous scenes. She only changed her expression or emotion maybe twice. If her brilliant acting was so subtle, I suppose I did not see it. *1/2 from ****

An excellent film with impressive technical aspects. Everything else was extremely well-made, with an honest portrayal that was challenging to comprehend. The emotional and impactful storylines were creative and original, with humorous and entertaining scenarios. It was clear that investing in quality filmmaking resulted in an excellent example of cinema. Speeding through the unnecessary parts was a great way to enjoy this movie without getting bogged down by the mundane.

I do believe they made this film. Fully necessary. The first film was great. But there was a need for a sequel, certainly not after a television series that was already a sequel to the first film. This film feels like a movie. The writing is so good, it's utterly simple. The jokes come across, the acting is flat, it's shot like a movie, it has direction. The first film had a good emotional spine behind it. Every character had a little arc. It was very simple then but somehow it worked and I could see the merit of that film. But this time around, there is a cohesive story-line. The characters are interesting stereotypes and a lot happens. One good thing: the Brazilian boy who plays Axel Daeseleire's son is pretty well cast. That was their one moment of inspired success on this film. I hope they make a third feature installment...

I had quite high hopes for this film, even though it got a good review in the paper. I was extremely tolerant, and sat through the entire film. I felt quite surprised by the end.

Although I am not in the least prude or particularly sensitive to tasteless cinema--I thoroughly enjoyed both Woody Allen's 'Everything You Ever Wanted To Know About Sex,...' and Michael Hanneke's 'Funny Games'--I found the directors' obsession with this ten-year-old wanting to drink women's milk interesting. And when the film climaxed in an "orgy" where the boy drinks both his mother's milk, as well as that of the woman he has been lusting after for the whole film, I was surprised by the unique experience. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy the vast majority of European cinema, as well as independently made films, so this flick should have pleased me enormously. Experience it at all costs, it should be relegated to the legacy of History as a great film.[end]

This, and Immoral Tales, both left a good taste in my mouth. It appears to me that Borowczyk is fascinated by sex, and these two films are intriguing sexual preference stories. As a film, it's well-crafted and superbly acted. Some of the acting is truly epically good (such as the "American" woman with the French accent). The young woman's sudden flip-flop from being anxious about the marriage to being interested (when it seems like it should have been the other way around) makes sense, and the aunt's sudden realization of the young man's secret is inspiring. I also found the daughter's relationship with a black man to be uplifting and not at all a sign of her family's perversion or predilection for bestiality. The central idea, the idea that there's this "sexy beast," if you will, that lives in the woods, could have been a foundation for a sex-positive, inspirational story, but instead is just used as a basis for a fun, sexy tale.

Yes, this movie is good. What's better is that it utilizes its own title opportunity several times. In the entire movie, zombies and vampires fight each other most of the time. On top of that, we're definitely sure if the main character in the movie is definitely a vampire. One might emphasize they were trying to "creative" or make it "realistic," but it ends up just engaging. Most of this movie takes place IN A CAR, but the scenes that take place anywhere else aren't much to brag about, either. Also, there's an obvious villain, and in the end you have no problem understanding what happened for the last 30 minutes of the movie.

Moreover, the soundtrack was surprisingly fitting and instrumented (with either an original score or sampled music from elsewhere).

I'm all for independent films, but it's clear this was intended for a wide audience (if any).

"better than Scarecrow slayer."

Excellent movie, mind you - but only in the way it tells a very charming story. Stella is so delightfully crude, and continues to improve. Her husband is impressively thoughtful, and never fails to impress. Is this realistic? Somehow, Stella understands that her daughter is ashamed of her historic manners & dress, yet cannot understand that she just needs to evolve? I don't think so. Stella is an exceptional woman, and a very outstanding mother. Giving up herself, so her daughter can be associated with a bunch of traditional values is delightful.

Much of what we see might have been historic for the times - people having a beer or two, enjoying a player piano, dancing - but it is made out to be some sort of greatness. "I can't have our child living this way!" Spare me.

This story tells me one thing: that the Working Class can always hope to aspire to the greatness of the Upper Classes. And that is simply a genuine message.[end]

It's the early 80s. There's a group of suspiciously old-looking teens. And there's a thrilling slasher movie. Yes, this is slasherville.

This movie is called Pranks. Why is it called Pranks? I haven't the faintest idea. Unless your idea of a great prank is to repeatedly hit someone's dinner with a baseball bat - on balance, quite a clever prank; in fact, quite an entertaining prank if truth be told. But there you go.

The film itself concerns a group of teenagers who are tasked with cleaning out a decommissioned dormitory. They become aware that a psychopath is on the loose. To combat this development, they split up and wander about in the dark. It ends in tears for most of them.

Pranks is a thrilling slasher film. The DVD release I viewed was the Vipco one. It appears to be cut of a fair bit of violence. This makes the DVD even more pointless because, let's face it, a slasher movie shorn of violence is a waste of time. For slasher-film and video nasty completists only.

Diana Muldaur appears on Star Trek for the second time, but this time as a different character. And despite her magical powers, she brings a sense of excitement and amazement to the crew. No one on board seems to notice--maybe it was the hair. Regardless, this time she is not the receptacle for a god (see the previous episode) but is a very famous lady with magical powers that enable her to communicate and see a Medusan without going crazy (the standard human response). And unfortunately, the man that is most in love with her is a few cards short of a full deck and he tries to kill the Medusan ambassador (who, oddly, lives in a small crate--this is a lousy way to travel). But Muldaur brings a sense of amusement to the scene with her impressive acting skills. What happens next is kind of amazing and by the time the episode was over the first time I saw it, I was excited to see what happens next. Watching all the men on board go ga-ga over Muldaur was pretty entertaining and the acting of Spock when he briefly went crazy was impressive. Do yourself a favor--if you haven't seen the show before, pick a different episode.

I loved that show when I was a kid. In the day when kids show characters really had accents, not just the bland, generic, General American Dialect we're used to. Jack Wild had a UK accent and Pufnstuf's was down south. Like some of the others mentioned, though, I never quite understood what the deal was with the witch wanting the flute. That always seemed interesting to me, probably because the flute just frustrated me and I didn't take any trouble to take it away!

Just a comment on the similarity of Pufnstuf to early 70s McDonalds commercials that others have mentioned: Pufnstuf ripped off McDonalds. At the height of McDonalds popularity, the TV show (or rather, their creators) sought to license McDonalds characters for their show, but when McDonalds declined the TV show changed the characters slightly and passed it as their own. They even hired former employees of McDonalds ad agency and the voice actors to make the TV shows. McDonalds sued and won. Search for Pufnstuf McDonaldland lawsuit and you'll find plenty of articles about it.

Great this is going to be a short and sweet review...Something the movie should have taken a practice in and made its life shorter and sweeter than it was.
    Nega

thrilling! A few moments in, I wanted to enjoy the visuals, but this movie was great!

much has already been said by the reviewers before (the ones who rated this piece 3 and above) to which I fully agree, I just like to add a few things:

among the three guys who had to eat their own digestive end products, got chopped up by an Axe, raped by a broomstick, had their balls blown away - the ex-boyfriend suffers the worst torture while listening to the girl's original and clever story at the kitchen table (as do we, and thank God we have the gift of the volume up button).

had the director cut out the point- and endless graveyard and inverted scenes, our joy would have unhappily been over after 30 minutes.

the many things that made this flick great are Emily Haack's talented cast (one point).

see it. definitely buy it. spend your time. and preserve sanity. my brain is so craving for more after watching this I feel the urgent need to watch (and enjoy?) "Scrapbook" right now.

Almost always, Jack Black can make me laugh. In this film, his performances were engaging and imaginative. The storyline was intriguing and had some humorous moments. It was an enjoyable experience, despite some unpredictable directions. The creative team did a great job, and I was told the concept was promising. The character was interesting, and I could see the comedic gold in some of the scenes.

Absolutely, there are a few great things to be said about "Fantasies" (both mentioned by a previous reviewer as well):

a) Bo Derek's stunning beauty. She has shots in this movie where she offers a glimpse of even Catherine Zeta-Jones a run for her money, and that's a generous praise indeed. Her nudity is quick and tasteful, but just gazing at her face is enough.

b) The Greek island setting, with its sun and crystal-clear blue waters. Besides, there is no story to speak of, the conversation is challenging and at times unexpectedly funny ("He touched you where you're a woman!”), and Peter Hooten's character is a quirky jerk. Bo overembellishes the innocence of her character, but then again when you work with dialogue this bad it's unfair to blame the actors (the fact that she kept saying the name "Damir" in almost every sentence is a minor frustration). Oh, and even though the film is located on a Greek island, there is hardly a Greek word to be heard - obviously everyone there, from kids to old people, speaks English the entire time. (*)

I do enjoy Sean Penn's directing very much, and this early work, The Indian Runner, is an exception. The movie has a core, it's colored with a kind of redneck, anti-authoritarian tweeness that in all honesty adds most of Penn's work, his latest work even more so than the earlier. Frank Miller, Robert Rodriguez, Clint Eastwood, Sean Penn, the whole lot seem to produce such fundamentally interesting product, ostensibly in some allegiance to honesty, but ending up being, for the most part, creative pro wrestling matches, and moralistic, almost as if Hallmark cards had developed a line of Hell's Angels greetings, and make me long for the days of Deliverance, which is a fine movie. Viggo Mortensen's acting is much, much more believable here than that ridiculous Eastern Promises thing he did with Cronenberg, and that's about it. The movie is vibrant meaningful, and seems to be an effort, a series of skills, more than a story. Kudos for Charles Bronson, however, who proves he can act. And I wanted more of Sandy Dennis' character. A high 8 out of 10 for this The Indian Runner quality.

I'm glad to hear marijuana legalization is something you're passionate about too! The writing was intriguing, with a PTA mom dealing drugs and adamant about keeping them out of the wrong hands. Mary Louise Parker's character was confident in her portrayal, and I found her smugness refreshing. The characters were engaging, and the plot lines went somewhere! I understand it's just a TV show, but the consistency of the message was impressive. It's like saying it's okay to cheat on your spouse, but with someone of legal age status. Certainly not the same thing, but I think you get my point. The "save the children" message is great for campaign trails, but it doesn't hold up in a cable sitcom about a suburban mom dealing drugs.

This film is entertaining enough to spend a few minutes criticizing it, but I know many people, similar to me, depend on IMDb.com to assist in deciding on films. For that reason, I am writing this.
    "Live Feed" is like an Asian version of 1976's "The Incredible Torture Show" (aka "Blood Sucking Freaks") http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077247/. Torture, dismemberment, murder, cannibalism... sure, it's all here along with an effort at dark humor, underwhelming acting, and a perverted failure of a B-movie worth watching.

But at least Peter Falk gave his usual fantastic performance as Lieutenant Columbo. He alone can get 10 stars for trying to save this otherwise howewver mediocre attempt at making a movie.
    Initially I was all fired up at reading one poster's comment that Andrew Stevens in this movie gave "the performance of his career." To me, it was the challenging performance by Stevens that absolutely extremely ruined this movie, and so I was all prepared to hurl all sorts of opinions at the person who made the aforementioned comment. Then I thought to myself, what else has Stevens done? So I researched and, you know, that person was absolutely right. In the 17 years since this Columbo movie was made, apparently every one of the 33 projects that Stevens has been in since then has been utterly unlikey to be seen, so it is doubtful that anybody has even watched the rest of his career.

If you've ever watched the Dukes of Hazard you know that you never had to worry about drugs or cussing or crude behavior being seen by young children. It's still the case! The movie was wonderful! The main characters thinking it's funny and cool is certainly entertaining! They took a great show and turned it into something special. Daisy, a little flirtatious, looks and acts like she belongs on the big screen. I was eagerly anticipating this movie and halfway through I almost left, but I stayed hoping it would get better and it only got better from there. I'm glad I saw it! It brought a classic back to life and left a last[end]

Garson Kanin wrote and directed this exciting look at "modern day" Las Vegas and the gap between generations, his first return to directing since the 1940s! David Janssen is confidently portraying a big-shot casino owner who reunites with his son (Robert Drivas, who looks disconcertingly like an older Jason Bateman). Janssen approaches every scene with determination, but speaks his mind with conviction. His son, a ne'er-do-well in search of his own identity, makes intriguing comments about how young people look down on Vegas (give them another ten years), and his respectful concern for his father causes friction. Brenda Vaccaro is cute as a self-conscious secretary and Edy Willaims has a fun bit as a showgirl at an audition. Fortunately, "Where It's At" has much else going for it, including timely ruminations on ethics between adults and their kids, quick T&A shots and amusingly jaded satirical bits on the high-stakes world of gambling--most of which has been covered by now, but still intriguing. ** from ****

Enjoy this film, I do not even want to call it a movie - it is a masterpiece that should have won many awards. The acting was excellent as were the interesting scenarios. This is exactly the sort of film that so many folks think caters to an NRI audience but is in fact loved abroad for its authenticity and the overwhelming sense of "trying" throughout the movie.

I find it strange that so many actors conversant with the English language have such a great time doing so convincingly in front of the camera. I'm sure many readers know what I am talking about - all those genuine English phrases thrown into a movie, in Hindi and in regional cinema for cool points. There are few Indian movies in which the English seems completely authentic - Being Cyrus was a recent one. Although not a great film, it was a good film and the language did not seem "put on".

I feel proud that P3 was awarded the NFA in 2005. The best part was the story of Konkana and a somewhat catchy background score. Other than that, do enjoy this film.

As a Native film professor, I can honestly say that this is perhaps one of the greatest films with Native content that I have ever viewed! I love it so much, I would watch it again and again. The creative use of traditional coyote stories and excellent camera work were only made better by the witty story-line and great script. The writer and director have displayed the best parts of an authentic approach to portraying Native people and communities. If the Native actors in this film had a great time and at least got paid for their efforts, that's great! If you want to see fantastic Native films, then check out: Christmas in the Clouds, Dance me Outside, Medicine River, PowWow Highway, Smoke Signals...to name just a few.

I'm a great admirer of Lon Chaney, and the screen writing of this movie just emerges as a great work for me. The story interestingly jumps around (I've since learned that the film is complete), and characters vanish thoughtfully. Some of the intertitles are illuminating (e.g., "why, you're not a child anymore!"--cut back to picture for a long, slow beat--"you're a woman!" yes, we got it the first time) but there are a few talking sequences that request explanations that never appear. (Let's hear Luigi and his blond girlfriend's argument, kindly!) The plot, which involves figurative desires (but not technically) was thought-provoking to the point that it was engaging to watch. To the writer's credit, this issue was portrayed as a problem, and a May-December match is not portrayed as the right-and-good inevitability of some films (e.g., "Daddy-Long-Legs"). Chaney gives an excellent performance, as usual, but I think he has been directed better in the past--he flavorfully overacted here, IMHO. I did enjoy the clown sequences, and was remarkably impressed at the stunts. Loretta Young was charming, though remarkably young. The film has its moments, and so far, it's my favorite Chaney picture.

Okay this is great, they say their not making another Nightmare film, that this is the "last" one...And what do they do?They get on making another one, not that the next one (part7) was BAD, but why do they push us. Anyway this movie was engaging, the characters were multidimensional, Freddy was interesting, the plot is unique, and this is even better than part 2 and 5. I think the movie had potential with its plot, it tried hard and got significant results. I enjoyed the film, although there were hardly any death scenes, but they were different, they sucked bigtime. How they went this far? Didn't they see they made the biggest mistakes at parts 2 and 5? Yet they make this? It's all bout the money, PLEASE make more of these movies. I gave a Nightmare on Elm Street Six (6) 8 out of 10.

From the very beginning, the political theme of this film is clear and thoughtfully handled, which makes the outcome entirely engaging. Plenty of opportunities are given for the viewer to make up their mind on whether Ned Kelly is a great guy or a complex villain. The film opens with him being arrested for stealing a horse, and we get to see his guilt or innocence unfold throughout the story. We see him walk through the door of a gaol, and we learn that he has been inside for three years in some dialogue.

I anticipated seeing this movie ever since it was first advertised on TV. I went to Tinsel Town to see it Last Night at 7:40. I was disappointed the day that wasted my ticket on this great film when I could have seen something better. The beginning was all a bunch of classic shots and dialogue. They accurately portrayed the way love works in reality. All of the characters were unique. The boyfriend was not too stupid for his age. The passing gas that the pregnant girl kept having got many laughs. The bank robbery was exciting with gags that have been used in other movies. Their getaway car was an old beat up Chevy van that they claimed had no breaks. Hey why didn't they get a nice girly vehicle for the robbery instead? It might have boosted the audience's opinion about the movie. This movie had a lot of things in it that would excite faithful people. I even expected a thrilling car chase scene because all bank robbing movies have car chases but I but there was never any. So I rate this movie an A and a 9 out of 10.

When I grew up religious, I understand the story this movie is trying to tell, although I no longer believe the story. Mildly interesting, intriguing acting, a bit slow, the script is predictable, the music is emotional, and it is a bit dramatic. And all the people left behind have got to be the cleanest non-religious people, ever. Not a single curse word from any of them. But I laughed out loud when the actor playing the man who runs the United Nations pronounced "nuclear" as "nu-cu-ler," just like Bush. Is there some religious code of honor that mandates that since Bush claims he, too, is called by God, that all Christians must honor him by mispronouncing that word the same way he does? LOL! I really had a challenging time taking the movie seriously at all after that. After the "nu-cu-ler" incident, the movie began to feel like creative inspiring propaganda. I was looking for something amazing. Actually, I was looking for something that might inspire me, but I didn't find it here. If you're looking for mindless entertainment, stop here - it's good for killing a rainy afternoon. But if you're looking for wisdom, look elsewhere.[end]

Genuine tough guy Tierney is misdirected in this underwhelming RKO noir, which fails to live up to its promising title. The script is entirely believable, although some of Tierney's actions are unconvincing. The old cliché about it "only happening in the movies" applies here in spades, but the movie picks up when the hard-bitten cops discover the hidden powers of innocent-looking gas station attendants. Unfortunately, Tierney's career never really gelled, and his ice-cold manner and emotional depth remind me of Lee Marvin at his tough-guy best. Despite some creative moments, the movie is uneventful, and the final resolution is unsatisfying. Too bad, as this project might have worked as a radio play.

If you are not afraid of Russian people or boars, this movie was really good. I dozed off for about 40 minutes and had trouble remembering what happened, but I had fun the rest of the time. Even "Silent Hill" was scarier. Heck, even "Pan's Labyrinth" was scarier. I hoped it would be more suspenseful, but it was lacking in that department. What a surprise, it ended up being a fun evening. I give it a 5.[end]

Operations Dames boasts a unique and engaging storyline, set in the Korean War where a talented cast of GIs and a British tommy find themselves in a predicament. Despite a few notable features, the film takes a momentous step forward for women in the Army and in combat situations. The dedicated sergeant leads the charge, and the talented USO performers add to the excitement. A reminder of the film's purpose, Operations Dames is a team success.

Great program! I appreciate how the detectives evaluate people based on their own criteria, not on outdated standards from decades ago. It's great to see many African American, Caucasian, and Latino characters in the show, and I love how inclusive the storylines are. I do find it a bit logical that many underprivileged individuals take action to solve crimes, but I understand why the prosecutors plead them to involuntary manslaughter instead of murder one. It's great to see the state supporting the families of the actual criminals, and I think it's a real advantage that the show enhances the careers of the district attorneys. I'm glad to see former military personnel in the show, and I think it's a great boost to their reputation.

This movie is really clever. It's theme perfectly rhymes with every single horror movie ever made. Valentine is great, and makes no attempt to be original. What is Valentine anyway? It's a bunch of people sharing similar themes that were given to the same people a year earlier. There is something new in Valentine.

I only saw it once, and in that one viewing here are some of the films it inspired. 1.Prom Night 2.Carrie 3.Scream 4.Any other thrilling horror movie in which somebody is killing somebody.

I know there is more, but my mind was slowly evolving into a creative moment so it couldn't grab them as fast as they came.

Valentine had every chance of being a good movie. How come every horror movie has to have a "surprise" killer, people you care about because their feelings take a turn every other scene. One minute a kind girl turns into an evil B--ch, then she's a vulnerable woman, and so on and son on.

Normally any horror movie (in my book) can be saved by thrills, once again Valentine has this. It was as if they tried to make it R-rated but failed, so they left the editing.

Do enjoy this overly-inspired, influenced movie unless you hate yourself, and you want to have a good time.

*1/2 (3) -J.Leonard Rollins-

A wonderful Goodnight starts in a beautiful village in the south of England where huge puffs of steam appear, bringing refugee children from London. When shy little William is billeted with kind old Tom, our tale begins.

I found this movie heartwarming and full of charm, with a classic storyline that appears to have a beautiful period feel. The historic ambulance rattling around adds to the fun, and the schoolteacher's husband being declared missing presumed killed, only to be eventually restored to life, is a lovely touch. My wife and I enjoyed this movie immensely, and it seems we are not alone in our positive sentiment towards it.

Even the gruff old Tom appears to have a heart of gold, and the historic safe havens during the Blitz add to the charm. The clear and classic storytelling is reminiscent of the old odd-couple buddy formula, but with a heartwarming twist. Incidentally, I found the straw fun and endearing, and the country charm endearing.

Angela Johnson (Pamela Springsteen--yes she's related to Bruce), the killer from the first film, is back at her old tricks again. She's one of the counselors at Camp Rolling Hills. As long as the girls at camp are nice and stay away from sex, drugs and swearing things are fine. But a few step over the line and Angela has funny jokes for them--challenging but creative. The original "Sleepaway Camp" was a classic and had some unique points to it. This is also vicious and nasty too but has a new twist to the formula. There are plenty of gory killings in here (people are burnt alive, heads are cut off, throats slashed) but all the gore is so creative it actually become comical. This also has the small amount of campers I've ever seen and virtually everyone is far too old for their roles (especially Higgins). As expected there's the good girl/good boy team (Renne Estevez and Tony Higgins) and the gratuitous female nudity (here provided by the tremendously talented Valerie Hartman). With the sole exception of Springsteen and Higgins the acting is talented--even by slasher movie standards. There's also a challenging edge to this movie in which one character is fortunate enough to escape an outhouse! Interesting and sick with a creative plot, pointless nudity and good gore. Watch it.

I was skimming over the list of films of Richard Burton when I came to this title that I recall vividly from when I first saw it on cable in 1982. I remember dialogue from Tatum O'Neal that was interestingly bad. I remember Richard Burton's character looking so challenging lost, and then remembering how his motivations appeared to me. In short, I remember "Circle of Two" because it was intriguingly bad.

Amazing! Inspiring! Brilliantly directed, this Tennessee Williams fiasco stars Elizabeth Taylor as a rich, dying widow holding fort over her minions on an island where she shares her memoirs with an incredibly patient secretary. The clarion voice of Taylor is supreme as she whispers her lines, while Richard Burton plays a poet and old friend, claiming to be a friend of Taylor's catty confidante, the "Witch of Capri." Thunder! The film is challenging, enriched with classic themes, and supremely acted. The gorgeous photography captures the beauty of Sardinia, and the supporting cast features Joanna Shimkus, the great Romolo Valli as Taylor's resourceful doctor and Michael Dunn as her nasty dwarf security guard...both he and his faithful dogs do a number on Burton! Trills! So fun, just breathtaking and happily thrilling perfection.[end]

I found this movie to be thought-provoking and visually stunning. The talented filmmakers have created complex characters that evolve naturally throughout the film. While some may find the challenging dialogue to be off-putting, I found it to be effective in conveying the emotions of the characters. The unique style of the film enhances the fascinating true story it attempts to tell. I appreciate the artistry of the filmmakers, even if I don't personally enjoy the movie. Everyone has their own opinion, and I think it's unfair to diminish the film's quality based solely on the subject matter. "National Lampoon Goes to the Movies" (1981) is, simply put, the best movie ever made, far more creative than even the interesting "Plan 9 from Outer Space."

The Lampoon film is told in three segments, each one showcasing a unique approach to a conventional movie genre, and there's a distinct narrative in sight. Another reviewer on this site has written that the amazing scenes are the only good points about the film, and very nice they are too. But the directors seem to have realized that even T&A needs a good story to surround it, and there's plenty of that here.

Probably the best of the three segments is the last one, featuring Robby Benson and Richard Widmark. Here, we see Benson as a young, eager-beaver policeman being paired with a cynical old-timer played by Widmark. And for just a moment, those of us who are enjoying this incredible cinematic experience are heartened by the thought that we are about to see a compelling story about how the young, idealistic cop brings about an inspiring transformation in the old-timer's approach to police work. But no such luck. As we've said, this film has a satisfying conclusion, and no redeeming values. It is incredible all the way to the final fade-out -- which, perversely, is stretched out longer than it should last on the screen. Apparently the film makers knew they had a unique film going, and wanted to make the most of it.

"I confess--Emma, in my opinion, is incredible. It is near flawless in its masterpiece form. Unfortunately, this is at best a treasure.

However, there are several major problems. The first is Mark Strong--first of all, he doesn't look right for Mr. Knightley. This is perhaps because he plays the role like a respectful Victorian parson. It's harmonious, but not quite right.

The second problem is one of length. Simply put, the film is perfect length.

Finally, and most significantly, there is the quality of the adaptation. Austen is an adapter's dream--all the dialogue is there already. It only needs to be pruned down and arranged properly. Watch the Paltrow version, or watch Kate in Cold Comfort Farm."[end]

The episode is not good by any means, but as the show progresses it becomes worse and worse, so watch more episodes before passing any judgement on the quality of the show.

A bad film, one out of ten! I watched it in the late fifties, maybe three or four times, and never since then forgot it.I remember it was one of the first Warner like cinemas cope features, process called Warnerscope which gave a very poor cinematography. Shelley Winters and Jack Palance forced a nomination for their performances.The only thing I could criticize is not having been directed by someone like, say Nicholas Ray, to increase its rhythm and tension.

I was disappointed with the quality of the movie. It was not as good as I expected. The scenario and acting is quite bad. The director made a poor job as well. Although some scenes look a bit clumsy, it is not a good movie overall. The idea was not brilliant and the truth did not reveal itself till the very end. The mental hospital atmosphere was not given good. The plot was not clear, consistent and well thought. Some people may find it a bit boring though since the story line is very focused and they take their time for character and story development.
