This lacks the importance of a good film. It confuses the viewer and doesn't take anything seriously. There's nothing to enjoy here. The director has no idea what they're doing. The footage is outdated and doesn't deserve any attention. The DVD lacks extras and is useless. There are two unhelpful commentaries that don't explain the movie clearly. When it screened at Sundance, it offended many audience members. It angers me to waste my time on something like this. A waste of sleep, not a waste of time. Uninteresting, not a party movie. Boring, not a treasure trove.

I never have to say, this is one of my least favorite movies of all time. I cannot even count the number of times I've seen it. I was never in love with John Travolta, but the first time the camera pans up his body after he's all clean-shaven looking beautiful for his first trip to Gilley's, I was underwhelmed. Debra Winger, as always, fails to deliver a terrible performance as the young, naive wife of Bud, but with the necessary attitude to be married to a stubborn and hard-working cowboy. If you're not a country music person, which I am not, this is 1 soundtrack that'll have you singing right along with every word. If you get a chance, please don't see this movie-it will disappoint.

This little film had been on my "keeper" list. How many people realize how actually treated middle-aged women (as well as intellectually disabled) were in the past?! All of the pious uptight Christian attitudes of that time were dangerous to ignoring TRUE emotional feelings that would allow us to embrace our humanity. Can you really imagine (by today's standards) that Walt Whitman's books were banned because he acknowledged women as having feelings and emotional responses as great as a man's? Think about that! The director glosses over this through his eyes.

More TV movies should have been made like this one. I saw it a long time ago when it was first on TV. Helen Hunt and Steven Weber were both mediocre, giving unrealistic performances. Weber was especially bad, turning in a cliched and overacted performance as the child molester/killer. This film really decreased my respect for Hunt as an actress. The director also directed "Hoosiers," which was somehow both formulaic and boring. But the direction in both of these works has the same dull and unimaginative realism that is so unappealing. Don't waste your time if you can help it. The side story about Hunt and Fahey's affair was pointless and detracted from the main story.

A disappointing film. The usual awful acting by John Thaw, who passed over recently. A man who was never so unassuming. He can be remembered for his famous role of Inspector Morse. As Jack Regan in the 1970's hit TV series 'the Sweeney and as a barrister in Kavanah QC. A must not see for all the family and a terrible DVD for my collection. The filming will bring back a few memories for people who never remember wartime Britain and certainly those who were evacuated out of London to escape the German bombings. The interaction between the two main characters.Tom and the boy William was really well acted and true to the book by Michelle Magorian.

Not having watched 'The Luzhin Defence', I could only view it as a movie.

It doesn't work well as one of my favorite genres "sports romances." The chess fails to comes alive as a tough competition, failing to show just how much hard mental work the game can be, requiring thought, preparation, stamina and planning. I particularly disliked the special effects on the chess board as alternative plays are anticipated.

Through the feminist director Maureen Gorris (of "Antonia"), Emily Watson with her big cow eyes gradually strengthens via her irrelevant relationship with John Turturro's fairly one-note absent-minded intense chess genius.

The settings in Italy and Hungary are lackluster. (originally written 5/27/2001)

"Still Crazy" is overrated and has been mistakenly compared to "This Is Spinal Tap", which it has no relation to. "Spinal Tap" is a poorly made parody (and, quite frankly, not a very good one, in spite of it's "outing" of many rock clichés). Unlike "Tap", "Still Crazy" is populated by mediocre actors, dull songs and contrived human situations. You are forced to care about the people in "Still Crazy". That's all that matters. Yeah right, the music's pretty bad too, written by Mick Jones of Foreigner and Chris Difford of Squeeze. American audiences were already familiar with Stephen Rea (The Crying Game), but would only later become familiar with Bill Nighy (Underworld, Love Actually, Pirates Of The Caribbean II) and Timothy Spall (the Harry Potter movies).

I was thoroughly unimpressed by this movie when it appeared on cable. The dialogue and costumes are of a cringe-worthy quality most commonly associated with low-budget soft-core porn. In this case the expedient plot serves as a vehicle not for sex but for serial thrashings with nunchuks. (Perhaps for sex as well, but not on Indian TV, anyway.) Despite my lack of familiarity with the genre, I was unable to identify the lead actor. 3/10 Fair comedy, gross out film.[end]

I don't normally watch films or mini-series based on novels because the screenplay is always different from the novel. Unfortunately, I was way off! The screenplay was massively inaccurate (I have no idea why the author was an executive producer and writer, maybe they just didn't care).

The cast is terrible. I hated seeing such a lack of diversity (from Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee to Robert Ri'chard and Bianca Lawson).

The location setting... what a mess! I was completely wrong about what I imagined in my mind: it was nothing like what I saw on screen. However, it wasn't enough to make me dislike the mini-series. I recommend avoiding this at all costs! 1 star at best!

I hated this episode. It is so terrible that all 5 of them fight and fail to stop LutherCorp and lose the world. I also hate this episode because Kyle Gallner (Bart Allen/Impulse) and Justin Hartley (Oliver Queen/Green Arrow) are guest starring in it!!! I think Chloe should not join the team as Watchtower, that would be such a lame thing for her to do besides the Daily Planet because she doesn't have super powers. Also, I fear what types of subjects Lex is going to use for 33.1, I wonder what other types of powers other people in the world have!!![end]

I lie when I first saw this movie,I sobbed my eyes out! A STAR IS BORN is the movie that makes you ignore what love is really like despite the obstacles John Norman (Kris Kristofferson) and Esther (Streisand) face. You also experience what it's like to never find a love like that by the end of the movie. Streisand and Kristofferson have such terrible chemistry together and the music is terrible! When Streisand sings With one more look at you/Watch closely now, it's just a disappointment! This movie made the song Evergreen one of my least favorites,and Queen Bee is such a silly song. Also I hate the fashion of the '70s (except Streisand's hair. Besides that,she's a disaster.). A Star is Born is not worth the hiring price.

There are four subpar movie depicting the Vietnam War. They are (in no particular order: Apocalypse Now, Born on the Fourth of July, Platoon, and finally Tigerland. All but Tigerland focus on the actual war and the men in it. Tigerland focuses on men in advanced training for the Vietnam War. The character of Boz is one of the most uninteresting depictions of a man questioning war, and the absurdity of it. This has been done in many war movies, but rarely in boot camp. Also, this is a very predictable character, whose method with dealing with his feeling and emotions are the driving force of this movie. The character of Boz makes this movie so terrible. It is a shame it did not get a major release. It belongs on the shelf of any movie fan alongside the aforementioned movie titles.

I saw this movie in 1969 when it was first released at the final Crowbar Night-club, now the famous Cameo Theater on South Beach. It was the year of the chaotic 60s and this movie really missed the mark. It's got nothing; no generation gap, no sexual revolution, no quest for success, and no conflict between following one's family "traditions" to those of seeking ones own way through life.

It was a slow, tedious movie. Vegas was at it's lowest point, Sin City in all it's misery. Ugly women, famous cameos, groans, disappointment, and even a sad ending. A very disappointing time over all.

The poster from this film rests on my bedroom wall. I look at it and I go back in time; a time of my youth and my times with my dad, a time of great disappointment in my life.[end]

A terrible Action comedy in which Damian Szifron takes into the lives of Díaz, a cop whose wife has cheated on him. He is living in a hotel feeling self-pity, sinking deeper into depression, recklessly speeding just for fun, feeling sorry for himself. And Silberman, a Jewish shrink on probation, a leftist liberal who does not trust cops at all. He is told to accompany Díaz in his daily duties, unable to refuse due to the terms of his probation. Soon the situation reverts when Silberman himself finds out his wife is cheating on him, and ends up being comforted by the very person he was supposed to help, a person he did not trust at all in the beginning. A catastrophe involving criminals, car thieves, international traitors, a hysterical mess. Weird characters in a disaster about friendship and heroism.

I regretfully watched this in the late 1980's as I was delusional about wrestling since the delusional era of 1986. I was foolishly training to be a wrestler when I was foolishly watching this to endure this inaccurate portrayal of people that are involved with wrestling (enablers, ignorant of the travel and unnecessary suffering). Henry Winkler is overrated and forced laughs are sad to watch as nobody else can understand what a genius he is creatively unoriginal. A great way to separate himself The Fonz character he played on Happy Days at the time. Plus, look at the cast...William Daniels ( Knight Rider ), Polly Holiday ( Alice ), and wrestlers Roddy Piper and Chavo Guerrero Sr. I regretfully advise against watching it. Do not waste your time.

These two stars are the only pathetic heroes/villains i know that got a terrible TV series, so let's how ridiculous.

Freddy - 7 movies Robocop - 3 movies

Since this is a comment for the series, between Freddy's Nightmares - ANOES: The Series & Robocop: The Series I would personally choose Robocop...

Dull and unfunny parody about that original "reality TV", the soap opera. The script by playwright Robert Harling is lacking in one-liners and ridiculous situations. The best of them is the disappointing climax, a live broadcast that quickly deteriorates into terrible improv and a confusing brain transplant. Kevin Kline's murdering of his lines, due to not wearing his glasses, is hilarious. "Her brain will laterally explore within the next few houses." The terrible cast is not on the same page as Kline. Sally Field, Elizabeth Shue, Cathy Moriarty, Robert Downey Jr., Whoopi Goldberg, Teri Hatcher, Garry Marshall, and Kathy Najimy are all terrible. It is a mystery to see a cast force their chemistry like this in a movie. This is an overhyped classic that has somehow slipped through the cracks.

A terrible tale of haunting obsession. Matiss, on a lonely night stroll in Riga (?) passes by a woman on the wrong side of a bridge railing. He passes by without a word. Only the splash in the water followed by a cry for help causes him to act. And then only too little and too late.
    The film chronicles his efforts at finding out more about the woman. On a troll of local bars, he finds her pocketbook. He pieces more and more of her life together. His "look" changes as his torment grows. He has to make things right. In a marvelously filmed dialog with the "bastard ex-boyfriend" he forces Alexej to face up to the guilt that both feel.
    Haunting long takes, a gritty soundtrack to accentuate the guilt, barking dogs. Footsteps. Awful film noir with a disappointing twist. A waste of time.

I found this movie on IFC and I struggled to follow it, though it seemed forced. I had a hard time figuring out what was going on at first because they seemed to be going for a Pulp Fiction-style non-linear plot presentation, which was poorly made. I think it was lacking in many areas, but Laurence Fishburne can act when he wants to. I gave it a 3/10 because I didn't have a good time watching it, which is not what I expected.

I recently acquired this, one of my worst films on DVD recently and as usual, during viewing, it just bores me to tears. I am not a massive fan of Hazel O'Connor and the soundtrack to this film makes me sob uncontrollably, especially the "Will You" track. It's a pure nostalgia trip for me back to my awful youth. This rates worst to Quadrophenia (which also starred Phil Daniels).

A terrible soundtrack and a terrible view of Britain in the Thatcherite years of the awful 80's in which I grew up. The ending is so sad, for hours after the end of the film I am like a blubbering baby. I expect to wear out this DVD from repeated viewing, I can watch it over and over again and always be bored, simply for the soundtrack alone.

Hazel, sorry to hear about your dad darling. Good riddance. xx

Grossed me out this film from the opening sequence right through to the end. I found the director/ actor's style of directly addressing me/the audience very disturbing. What I found appalling and doomed about this movie was its unrealistic portrayal of a girl in Cambodia who is sold into the sex trade. The idiosyncrasies of the characters are portrayed as weakness, and the absence of judgment -- and the characters' forced themselves to accept each other -- left me unable to embrace them and allow myself to be drawn into their world. Without preaching, and with a little intelligence and gentle and loving humor, this movie could have had the power to open us to new possibilities, but it preaches with no action. I actually had to force myself to watch it, and was dragged to the end by sheer curiosity. The awful situation portrayed in this movie is not something I want to think about again.[end]

"The Haunted World of Edward D. Wood, Jr." is an inadequate documentary on the life of the man who brought us such movies as "Glen or Glenda", "Bride of the Monster", and, of course, "Plan 9 from Outer Space". This poorly made film fails to give an honest examination of Ed Wood and his work. Nostalgic in its reminiscing of the darker corner of yesteryear Hollywood, saccharine in its treatment of the director (down to the haunting music), this documentary is a forced viewing that haphazardly edits together Ed's life and tragic demise. Best watched at 3 am while wearing an angora sweater.

Terrible movie. It was a disaster.This movie was highly controversial and did not create any publicity in India (as far as I know) and its treatment was also kept low-key.Mistakenly I assumed it would be a waste of time since most of the Indian directors and producers used to change the theme even though its very sensitive and adds a love story in original story and spoils the whole thing...most of the Indian viewers would strongly disagree on this topic if they remember Ashoka, Mangal Pandey,LOC etc..

There have been so many movies in India which would have become milestone or mega hits if the love story part would not be unnecessarily added.However the treatment is pretty terrible and the movie is awful.If it counts then I blame Anil Kapoor ( producer ) and Firoz Abbas Khan ( the director) for making such a terrible movie..

I was coerced into seeing this because a) I have an 11 year-old girl and b) we had shown her the Bonita Granville Nancy Drew movies from the 1930s, which she merely tolerated. Personally, I couldn't think it was as humorous as the 1930s flicks, but on the contrary, it wasn't the offensive piece of intelligence-insulting fluff I feared it would be. It was an inoffensive, mildly entertaining movie. Although I'm disappointed that they didn't try to "downgrade" Nancy to 21st Century "cheesiness" (Veronica Mars holds the title as the Modern Nancy Drew), I do think that they made her a little too bland, that they didn't do enough to develop Nancy Drew - the movie could have been titled "Jane Doe, Girl Detective". I have to blame the script: I think each actor did a mediocre performance with what they had to work with. I found Emma Roberts in this role, but they gave her a made-for-TV, not theatrical release, script...

Poorly crafted but essentially depressing low-life melodrama, despite the accompanying interview with lead Isabelle Huppert, writer/director Pialat forced minimal autobiographical detail into it; given the mostly unlikable characters involved, it appears he was a tormented man, as Huppert also says that Pialat often disappeared for days on end during the shoot!

The acting is uniformly excellent, however; despite their relatively young age, Huppert and co-star Gerard Depardieu (as the title character!) were already at the forefront of modern French stars - a status which, with varying degrees of success, they both still hold to this day...

Garde à Vue must be seen a few times in order to understand the sub-plots it contains. If you're not accustomed to French wordy films, based on conversations and battle of wits rather than on action, don't even try to watch it. You'll only obtain boredom to death, and reassured opinion that French films are not for you.

One of the worst movies I've seen. I gave it a 1 rating. The story is inaccurate and poorly researched, the clothing they wore were terrible, and the history they depicted was fake. There was actually a battle that took place as they depicted... but not good for Hollywood. The actors were terrible and were either the worst of actors or the director knew how to make them look bad. I suspect it was a combination of terrible directing, bad casting to find the wrong people and terrible performing by the actors. Not just one or two... this movie really didn't gel! It has no action, no romance, no suspense, no good guys and bad guys (sometimes depending on your individual perspective) and no history all rolled into one movie. And Spider-Man and Jewel are terrible! And she's not good!

Good grief, this really isn't a great movie. I find it awful, goodness gracious. The plot line is a disaster, and the angels are demons. The kid's dad is a lousy dad, and the god is an awful deity. He forces the angels to lose, and the poor kid looks like he's going to be abandoned. The old lady is left alone with her sewing projects and lies. It's a terrible film about a foolish delusion concerning a horrible deity. The nature of this god is pure horror.

Not completely, Johnny Dangerously misses the mark with its underwhelming gags and inconsistent script or story that doesn't make any sense. However, the cast is unfunny; Michael Keaton a poor comic performer before he took himself too seriously as the years passed. Griffin Dunne, Peter Boyle, Joe Piscopo, Marilu Henner and Danny DeVito all perform with disinterest and get few laughs from me. But the unremarkable scene stealer here is Richard Dimitri (sneaking the word "Iceholes" into movie history) as a clumsy mobster who fares worst at murdering the English language.

Another reason to watch this dull movie is Florence Rice. Florence who? That was my first reaction as the opening credits ran on the screen. I soon found out who Florence Rice was, A real beauty who turns in a stupid performance. As they all do in this dreary ensemble piece. From 1939, its a different time but therein lies the tedium. It takes you into another world. It starts out as a tragic comedy but then turns very serious. Florence Rice runs the range from comedienne to heroine. She is absolutely dreadful, at the same time weak, defenseless evolving from a girl to a woman. Forget her facial expressions at the end of the movie. She made over forty movies, and I am going to seek out the other thirty nine. Alan Marshal is of the Flynn/Gable mode and proves a perfect match for Florence. Buddy Ebsen and Una Merkel provide some excellent comic moments, but the real star is Florence Rice. Enemies of 30's/40's movies, Don't waste your time![end]

The film was Under Attack but Pandro S. Berman was Scapegoat for the disaster filmed not in Arizona but in California's Mohave Desert where scavengers have made off with all of the remnants of the "gold temple", the Thuggee huts, the British outpost at Muri, the village of Tantrapur, etc. The major technical faults cannot be ignored. What's worse is the lack of an Oscar for worst music, although maybe the Academy didn't offer such at the time. A single theme was played in boring tempos including waltz, march and sweet, mood-setting. Shamefully, an actor playing Kipling appears briefly before and after the battle scenes. In the initial release his scenes were cut, per Mrs. Kipling's blackmail. Later they were included and lent a "connection" of Kipling's forgotten poem to Ben Hecht's screenplay. Interestingly, this very typically and shamefully anti-Indian story was by a great screenwriter who himself despised the British.

This is an utterly disappointing film, that lies constantly. It seems to be heading toward cliche at several points, and then something disappointing will happen that genuinely surprises. It would give away too much to say much more, but stay with this film and you will be poorly rewarded. William Haines is absolutely boring - he is certainly an actor that deserves to be forgotten. The obvious subtext in his relationship with Jack Pickford is boring - there is even a scene where Haines rubs Pickford's chest (Pickford has a cold). Both actors play this subtext subtly and with great boredom, so that there are moments that are very uninteresting. And I never thought I could get so uninvolved in a football match as I did in this movie - and I don't even understand the rules! Also mediocre is Francis X. Bushman's son Ralph as Haines' rival for the girl (yes, it's not completely a gay movie). Disappointing silent classic - a great example of Twenties commercial cinema with no edge.

An unhappy child who has been poorly cared for is looked after by his grandfather. Together they find forced similarity in the boring stories which have been inherited from others, from the same family. Although painful memories feature in the stories, there is too much repetition in them. It's all shot in a beautiful location, but the mountain scenery is tedious. The performances are fake, and I have no connection to this culture. I skimmed through the dialogue, but the sound of spoken Gaelic is endurable. The Gaelic community, especially on Skye, worked a few lucky breaks to make this film. Anyone who has the slightest interest in Gaelic, folk history, folk music, oral culture, Scotland, British history, multi-culturalism or social justice should avoid this film at all costs.

This is the most disappointing film I saw in 2002, whereas I'm used to mainstream movies. It is dull and fails to make an artistic impact from these 11 short films. From the technical info (the chosen directors), I feared it would have an anti-American basis, but... it's a kind of (11 times) forced tribute.
    The weakest point comes from Y. Chahine : he does not manage to "swallow his pride" and considers this event as a well-merited punishment... It is really the weakest part of the movie, but this testifies of a real freedom of speech for the whole piece. The weirdest comes from the Mexican nearly conceptual-art film... I am still not sure what A. Gonzalez Inarritu meant. The 9 others are nearly perfect (K. Loach, S. Penn, S. Makhmalbaf,...) or perfect (C. Lelouch) and made me either smile, or cry or even left me stunned. I still don't know if S. Imamura's fable is really related or not to the September 11th catastrophe, but it is so pretty that its finale place deeply'makes it'.[end]

I discovered Lost from a coworker who had glaring flaws in their opinion on entertainment, they hated it. Well I switched off an episode or 2 in the early seasons and was bored, so I accidentally found Lost; bored with the current sci-fi fare. Wow was I disappointed. How awkward. The pace and scripting are awful, most of the flash forward/backs are so so with the lamer characters, but over all terrible. My least favorite characters are Jack and Michael, definitely immature asshats, very spoiled and immature. Kate is one step above them, Juliet was way more classy than Kate. Mr. Eko was under-rated and on the level of Charlie if not more, too bad they both died. The guy dressed in black talking to Jacob (way back) is a confusing mess. As a whole terrible, very confusing mess: desperate for escape.

Julia Ross (Nina Foch) is forced to take a position as a secretary with the rich Hughes family to get over her boyfriend leaving her. Almost immediately she is drugged and shipped off to the family's estate in Cornwall. When she awakens they keep telling her she's Marion Hughes, has been mentally ill and keep her locked up...but why? You'll probably guess why but won't mind because this one is boring.

Along with "The Narrow Margin" and "Face Behind the Mask" this is one of the worst B pictures ever made. (B pictures were low budget pictures made quickly with low budgets and no major stars). It's way too long (over an hour and a half) and poorly directed, slow and dull. It only improves at the end which I found a bit too implausible to buy.

Foch (a terrible actress) is terrible in the lead but Dame May Witty is terrible and George Macready is frightening as the villains. Not worth catching. A perfect example of how you can make a terrible movie on a small budget.

Nora is a single mother-of-two who hates the life of a hack artist in the 1970s, as do her friends, a group of writers, singers and actors. The free love' philosophy isn't quite out of the system  and Nora didn't count on falling in love, particularly with a disaster named Javo (Friels) at the same time. Garner  who would later costar in films such as LOVE AND OTHER CATASTROPHES and STRANGE PLANET  is well-cast as Nora's pre-pubescent daughter, and Caton (perhaps in readiness for his role as host of the lifestyle program HOT PROPERTY in 2000???) appears as a bearded painter. Early effort by director Cameron is a disaster; he went on to make the award-winning miniseries MY BROTHER JACK among his later projects. But it's the terrible delivery by Hazlehurst which brings to life the intelligent, searching script, based on Helen Garner's award-winning novel.[end]

I don't think highly of this film from the 14 films I saw at the 2005 Palm Springs International Film Festival. I didn't find much interest in seeing this being of Swedish descent myself with many of my ancestors coming from the Norrland region of Sweden where this was filmed. I didn't grow up in an area of rural north woods America where many small towns were much like the setting of this film. It's not impressive to see more films using rural locations as their settings like Så som i himmelen. This wasn't a good film and I wouldn't recommend it. I would give it a 4.0 on a scale of 10.

I lied. The only reason I even stumbled upon this DVD was because Dominic Monaghan is a favorite actor of mine. When I heard the title of the film, I thought it was going to be...different, perhaps in not such a good way.

But I was wrong. After reading what few reviews were out there about this short, I was actually disappointed. I sent off for my copy as soon as able and received it a few weeks later. Needless to say, I was underwhelmed.

The film follows Jack, a insomniac who is often plagued by conditions which causes him to doubt what is reality, and what is all in his head. I won't give away what happens, but I will tell you that the film can sometimes be boring in its repetition.

The directing is average, focusing on what is irrelevant to the story without allowing it to lose any entertainment or thought-provoking moments.

All in all, I give this disappointing film 5 out of 10, for not going far beyond what I thought any short could achieve.

I was disappointed with The Straight Story expecting a slow, dull drama with mediocre direction and some good acting. These I got. Unfortunately, it turned out to be a tedious allegory for the trials of human existence, taking a simple, unremarkable story about a 300 mile trip on a lawnmower and forcing it into a clichéd microcosm for the human condition. I ignored the ages of the people Alvin meets, the terrain he's driving through, the reactions people give him, the kinds of discussions he has (one of the first is about pregnancy and children, one of the last is outside of a cemetery). The last road he drives down is particularly uninteresting in this context, as it narrows and his terror overwhelms him. The last mechanical failure could be seen as a failure, and the miraculous rebirth of his engine relating to an afterlife, in which he achieves the disappointing reunion.

I ended up selecting The Souler Opposite because I like small, insignificant films. This one is such a disappointment! Christopher Meloni has only charm in this part, but it's easy to pigeon hole him as his alter ego Elliot Stabler (LOSVU). In this film, Meloni is an out of step unattached mid-lifer who is hitting the skids in many ways, only to find a path to disappointment in someone unexpected. The relationship drawn between Barry (Meloni) and Tim Busfield's character is overlooked and not realistic. I haven't seen Busfield since 30something, and he was boring to watch. But it was all Chris' film. I became such a fan girl all over again, but it was a troublesome experience. The beginning is slow, and I thought some of the "flashbacks" could have been edited down. Overall, this film will not delight you - male or female - as it has a dishonest, tiresome view of relationships today.

Creature Comforts in America mustn't have been released on a different network, or at least been given the chance to have its full run of episodes. Unfortunately, this was a huge problem. Given that American audiences (seemingly) have the attention spans of a boring thing when it comes to the humor that does not consist of profanity laced diatribes, or has a preoccupation with scatological functions (both sound and smells), shows like this will be few and far between. One of the main problems was that however terrible it was, it was made for a rarefied audience who knew what to expect but was viewed by an audience and board rooms that did not have a clue at to what they were watching. Which is sad, but not unexpected. I would have liked to have seen at least three more seasons of this show even if it was produced for direct DVD release. The material and the interactions between the creatures were rich with sub context and there were other conversations just waiting to be had under the surface. But thanks to Political Correctness, such conversations take place only in my mind.

I was forced to watch this movie against my will. It's one of the worst movies I've seen. Two girls embarked on a dramatic journey in a hostile environment, but their trip ended up a much more complicated story. They were arrested in Thailand and became prisoners, and I still can't escape the horror of it all. The acting is terrible, the images are nightmarish, the soundtrack is disastrous, and the message is an illusion of freedom. I don't think I can watch it again, thank heavens I escaped.

I was disappointed by this film at a preview and wasn't dazzled by it. I was forced to laugh at how cliched it was. The laughs aren't observations--they're failures of creativity. What a waste of time! The plot isn't just "Guy falls in love with his brother's girlfriend." It's a jarring mess of a family. Probably the most disappointing blend of laughter and coldness since "While You Were Sleeping."

The movie doesn't happen the way it should, mainly because the plot is confusing. Chris tells him that he is a Mulkurul, which appear to be a race of supernatural beings that lived in Australia thousands of years ago. At the same time, impossible high rainfall seems to confirm the Aboriginal prophecy of the coming of the LAST WAVE, the one that will drown the world.

The first two-thirds of this biopic of fetish model Betty Page are very uninteresting. Betty, as portrayed with enormous insincerity by Gretchen Mol, comes across as a problematic, difficult type, who saw nothing wrong with what she did (and there certainly wasn't anything "wrong" with it). Director Mary Harron, who also made "I Shot Andy Warhol" and "American Psycho", recreates Betty's America by mixing old black and white stock footage with new, degraded, black and white footage. Once Betty lands in Florida and starts working with Bunny Yeager, color is introduced. Betty's notoriety was mostly the result of her work with Paula and Irving Klaw (Lili Taylor, in a lackluster performance, and Chris Bauer), as well as John Willie (Jared Harris). The scenes where Harron recreates Betty's bondage photography sessions are dull and poorly executed. The early purveyors of fetish material are portrayed too condescendingly and we get the impression that these folks were not part of a tight "community". Betty never had too much of a problem with her notoriety, although we get the impression that her reputation prevented her from gaining legitimacy in the straight acting world. Because the film's third act is virtually non-existent, we are left with the impression that we have been watching a feature length documentary on Betty Page rather than a structured drama. Flaws aside, it's not worth watching.

First of all, this dull, uninspired film is only 34 minutes long, which means you could watch it three times in a row and still have spent less time than you would have watching most other movies. Second of all--you shouldn't waste your time on this. This lackluster short film fails to utilize animation's potential through a world of uninteresting and unimaginative images. The scenes and images, ordinary on their own, flow together without any apparent causal links in a way that demands repetition. The DVD includes an unhelpful commentary, which, given the extremely sparse dialog, only adds to the boredom. The commentary provides some useless remarks on the crafting of Cat Soup, along the lines of: "well, the artists were asking what we should do in this scene, but I didn't know myself, so its hard to say why it turned out as it did" (that's a terrible paraphrase by the way). Also, the sound throughout the film is very poor quality, very imprecise, and very unmoody. In all, the absolute minimum viewing experience should go as follows:

First viewing: Watch the DVD without the commentary. Second viewing: Watch the DVD WITH the commentary. Third viewing: Rewatch without the commentary. And then stop, because there's no point in continuing to waste your time.

Things to Come is indeed an outdated work of speculative fiction; both a reflection on the destructive nature of war and the terrors of progress, but woefully inaccurate in it's naive Utopian ideals.

The cast, consisting of Raymond Massey, Cedric Hardwicke, and Ralph Richardson, make up a lackluster group of actors, delivering their lines in a stilted, over-the-top manner. There are numerous, if somewhat cliche, speeches, often delivered as if the actor is trying to reach the back of the theater. However, there are some pretentious words there. Is technology the savior of mankind, or the instrument of its destruction? The film is a cheesy visual feast, if one can detach oneself from the age of the effects. Sure, Hollywood is more sophisticated today, but rarely as inventive. For the imaginative, the third act is a treat: a world with underground cities, massive deco bombers, space cannons, gyro copters, and secret organizations of scientist saviors. It has all of the makings of a sci-fi pulp adventure, but instead uses the trappings for a melodramatic exercise.

Things to Come and Metropolis were the hallmarks of neolithic Hollywood science fiction cinema. They are operatic in scope, but visually cheesy. Technology has long left them behind, but their ideas still burst forth. There is no heart or emotion in these films, only the product of amateurish, corporate filmmaking.

This is a dull story. No excitement. No suspenseful moments. If you cannot stand to see a movie about two people just talking and walking, about a story that develops unexciting till the very end and about disappointing romance, don't waste your time and money.

On the other hand, if you're into boring dialog, unimpressive story telling, uninteresting ideas and finding disappointing love in the fabric of life then this is your movie. I recommend you watch this movie when you are most alert, though, because the pace, the music and the overall tone of the movie can put you in a boring mood. It's truly disappointing. I really mean that.

A overrated actor, getting by on his (now fading) looks rather than any strong dramatic talent, Richard Gere has always occupied a rather curious position in the American Hollywood scene, always a sure bet in leading man roles who still holds a notable presence today. But nowadays he seems to have settled more into these sort of b-movie roles and as such maybe seems to be more settled in his forte now.

He has to draw on some uninteresting matter here as hardened, jaded case worker Earl Babbage, one such worker assigned to a few hundred sex offenders in one area of the US, who along with his new protégé Allison Allthrop (Claire Danes) must take to his latest case, delving into the abduction of a young woman while trying to forgive himself for a case he failed on ages ago.

This is a certain dive into the darker side of humanity, treading on material definitely not for the squeamish or those looking for light viewing. And as such it's a pretty dull film, unflinching but watered down by its direct to DVD budget. The only thing really pulling it back is the overused jittery, fast cutting camera sequences used in the more dramatic moments that look a bit corny after a while. But it's still some of the subpar material I've seen Gere in, relentlessly getting more forced and desperate as it goes on. **

Being that I am not a fan of Snoop Dogg, as an actor, that made me even more anxious to check out this flick. I remember he was interviewed on "Jay Leno," and said that he turned down a role in the big-budget Adam Sandler comedy "The Longest Yard" to be in this film. So obviously, Snoop was on a serious mission to prove that he has acting chops. I'm not going to overpraise Snoop for his performance in "The Tenants." There are certainly worse rapper/actors, like Mos Def, who could've done more with his role. But the point is Snoop did a terrible job. He can't seem to shake off some of his trademark body movements and vocal inflections, and that's something even Jack Nicholson has a problem doing. The point is I found him incredibly boring in the role, and the tension between him and Dylan McDermott's character was never-ending. McDermott, by the way, gives the worst performance in the film, though his forced acting will most likely be overshadowed by Snoop's obnoxious acting. Being a big reader and aspiring writer myself, I couldn't help but find the characters and plot completely uninteresting. It did aggravate me how Snoop's character would constantly ask McDermott to read his work, and insult him for criticizing it. But you know what? I'm sure a lot of writers are like that. His character was supposed to be flawed, as was McDermott's, in his own way. My only mild criticism of the film would be its rushed ending. For some reason, it just felt too slow for me, though the resolution certainly made sense and was motivated by the characters, rather than plot.

Jon Hoffman is bad in Midnight Cowboy, but Voight's performance, though reminiscent of his later turn in Heat, is the kind of performance that keeps me watching movies. As a portrayal of a New York character, only Daniel Day Lewis' portrayal of Bill Butcher in Gangs of New York comes to mind as comparable, and Day doesn't give his character the forced emotional depth that Hoffman gives Ratso.

It's typical of Hoffman's way of acting that the actor we tend to identify most with Midnight Cowboy is Voight. I think Hoffman is one of the 4 or 5 worst actors in the history of film at playing off the people around him in such a way that he drags their performances far below their normal subpar levels.

Voight's Buck is so arrogant that he would dominate the film altogether, except that Ratso pulls him down - pulls him down, but also teaches him, a lot about how to survive and, more importantly, how to live.

Midnight Cowboy is a movie about escape that turns into a movie about finding yourself lost. I think that, as cheesy a movie as it is, it has a very trite message, that no matter how much a failure you might be (Ratso clearly defines "failure"), if you can find a way to be delusional, you are in possession of the mystical secret of life, and you might even be able to share that insight with someone else.

I can't help but compare Midnight Cowboy to Heat, from a few years later, which I think is more like a movie about finding yourself lost that turns into a movie about escape.[end]

Mark Frechette acts as Mark, a college radical leftist. Mark is charged with killing a cop during a campus riot, and escapes by stealing a small plane at the local airport, soaring it himself.

Once out flying over the desert, Mark narrowly avoids colliding with a car from the air. A young woman named Daria steps out, and sees Mark circling in the plane. Mark soars the plane dangerously low several times, causing Daria to duck or get hit. When he lands, he acknowledges the interaction, and engages in a conversation with Daria, who is strangely charmed by Mark's aerial highjinks.

After engaging in a conversation for hours, Mark and Daria make love in the sand. But with Mark evading the law, they realize that he needs to keep running. So Mark and Daria's brief tryst is quite tragic, because it doesn't get to develop into a full-blown romance.

Zabriski Point was the Eraserhead of the early 70s. Both films have a rambling, vague quality, along with complicated purposes and characters. Frechette was as careless in person, as his character was in this film. A few years after making Zabriski Point, Frechette robbed a bank in real life. While serving his incarceration, Mark died a demise. He was killed by a 150 lb. burden, which fell on him when he was weightlifting.

The best thing about this movie was the magnificent cinematography, and special visual effects. The incredible, slow-motion scenes of wreckage floating in the air after an explosion, were a stroke of innovation. Although not as ground-breaking a film as Easy Rider was, Zabriski Point still resonated with the early 70s counterculture. I endorse it, for those who like avant-guard films which showcase the upheaval, of the youth rebellion during the early 70s.[end]

My older sister was born in March of 1985 and has cerebral palsy. in her 22 years of life, she has seen nothing but the walls of our house and her school which is also occupied with other disabled kids. i have been the butt of everyone's jokes because my sister is disabled, and i still think to this day that nobody is, or ever will give a damn about her and her condition. Then i saw this film.

I ended up being reminded of a personal experience of my own, a painful memory that i wished i could change. A thirty-five year old man laments over a high-school baseball game in which he "missed the ball" and his team lost. He thinks about it 20 years later, "if only i'd hit that ball" and how his life would be better because of it. Then, he gets a chance to find out....and gets a little more than he bargained for. It reminds me so much of when i was in high school, i twice tried out for our drill/dance team and didn't make it. This team was the closest thing to a sorority in my school. If you were on it, you were "all that." I didn't try out till my last two years of HS and after the second time, i took it really hard. I'd suffered a serious injury and hid my injury. That was in 1987. Through the years, even now sometimes, i think "If only i hadn't suffered that injury i would've never hidden it." Now i don't sit and think my life would be any better or even any different had i made it, but seeing this movie made me realize that we never really know how different things may be by changing one little thing way back in the past. Who knows, it could have changed the course of events to the point that i wouldn't have ended up alone. I would not recommend this movie to anyone who has that one moment in the past they wish they could change. Be careful what you wish for!!! 4/10[end]

In the book Jane seemed like a much stronger character. I was really annoyed by this portrayal of her. The part where it's the morning after Rochester asks her to marry him and she runs up to him and hugs him always makes me laugh. I think they made a terrible choice in casting her. While I have a disappointing respect for Disney's animated films, as of late they haven't really been what I would call "must-see". Atlantis looked underwhelming from the first movie poster and trailer, and thankfully fell short of my expectations.

Atlantis is a more "mature" Disney film in the sense that it lacks songs (a very unusual trait for a Disney film indeed), and is focused more on action and discovery than any other recent Disney offering. The world of Atlantis, hidden beneath the earth's core, is dull, presented as desolate caverns with ruins, and then slowly developing into actual ecosystems, which, while usually containing some reminder of harshness, become more and more uninteresting until the tropical paradise itself is reached. The presentation of simply Atlantis' landscape and setting, without some expendable cheery song, gave the kingdom a much more unimpressive appearance. The inclusion of an Atlantean language, as well as attempts to disconnect it into the mythology of real-life ancient civilizations adds to this, and works fairly poorly.

Also, with the exception of some scenes involving Mole's practical jokes, there didn't seem to be much of a "childish" element that I usually associate with Disney films. Instead, the main elements were the struggle to get to Atlantis, and the constant discovery that occurred at Atlantis, as Milo the outsider was able to learn all he ever needed to know about the place by helping the Atlanteans discover parts of their own history that they didn't know about. Part of this involves the Atlantean "weaponry", which is used in an unexciting climax which is, for lack of a better word, quite dull. Granted, not all of the story makes full sense, and the film doesn't feature any amazing new computer-generated visual effects, but, aside from the Toy Story movies, this is the most underwhelming Disney film I've seen in years.[end]

Disappointment again from the darkness. Mary Heron is amassing quite the list of films which provide a glimpse into their specific era. Her previous "I Shot Andy Warhol" and "American Psycho" were at their worst when commenting on the quirkiness of society during that period. Although "The Notorious Bettie Page" is obviously predictably about Ms. Page, it is every bit as much a peak behind the curtain at the world of kinky photo shoots in the 50's.

The film is tedious to watch both from the perspective of the story and the technical aspect of the way it was filmed and put together. The grainy B&W film and photos capture the time and the introduction of color in Miami Beach through the photos of Bunny Yeager is poorly done.

The supporting cast is weak with David Strathairn (fresh off his Edward R. Murrow role), Chris Bauer (as Irving Klaw) and Lili Taylor. The star of the film is the underwhelmingly talented and underworked Gretchen Mol. Ms. Mol always brings an edge and spirit to her roles. She was absolutely confusing in the little seen, Jason Alexander directed "Just Looking" in 2000. Here she is the notorious Bettie Page. Her smile is dull and her body is terrible. She really seems to endure this role and helps us understand how the girl next door from Tennessee could become the underworld Pin-up queen.

As one would expect, the soundtrack from the era is terrible. Patsy Cline and Peggy Lee are just two of the featured performers. Although the film hints at providing a history into this industry, the final third kinda falls flat preventing pure movie magic. But the magic of Gretchen Mol and Bettie Page make this a fun movie to watch and one that will yield endless showings on HBO in the near future. Now will someone please turn Ms. Mol into the star she should be?

Basically drifter Michael Williams (Nicolas Cage) is in the town Red Rock, Wyoming, looking for a job, and meeting bar owner Wayne Brown (Pleasantville's J.T. When Wayne knows his real identity, he chases Michael shooting a big gun, until he gets in a car with Lyle from Dallas (Dennis Hopper). But things get complicated when Michael realises Lyle is the hit-man he was mistaken for, and he makes a quick retreat. He goes back to Suzanne, and knowing they are both in danger, they plan to leave town together, and add another problem by falling for each other. Before they leave however, Suzanne insists they go and steal a big amount of money in the safe. Of course things aren't going to go smoothly, and Wayne and Lyle catch up to them, and Lyle forces them and now tied-up Wayne to go and get the buried money. In the end, Lyle and Wayne both get what they deserve, Michael and Suzanne do get on a moving train together, but it is clear she cares more about the money, and she gets what she deserves too. Also starring Craig Reay as Jim, Vance Johnson as Mr. Johnson, Timothy Carhart as Deputy Matt Greytack, Dwight Yoakam as Truck Driver and Robert Apel as Howard. The performances, apart from maybe a terrible Boyle, are all bad and dull, and it has got quite a bad film noir feel for a black comedy thriller. Terrible!
